questions.question_text:
A network administrator received a ticket about intermittent poor performance of a manufacturing device. The engineer who submitted the ticket states the issue occurs when the device is sending or receiving larger volumes of network traffic. The physical copper path between the device and the switch tests successfully.
Which of the following should the network administrator do NEXT?

discussion.content:
First I thought the answer is port aggregation which is implementing a solution .
 But when read carefully I found that this is the first steps of trouble which is finding symptoms of issue. So the answer is correct.
Since it says manufacturing device I would think that the cables should be shielded?
Doesnt make sense because if there was a speed or duplex mismatch then the connection wont work or be slow all times, not specifically to large data size

comments.content: Well if it was a speed issue then you won't notice it when you're not sending enough normally to reach the max speed limit. However when sending/receiver larger volumes you'll hit that speed cap, so I could see this being correct.

discussion.content: I hope to get all the 90 questions in the exam where the answer is Hash
hash - check integrity of the patch is same with vendor
Hash is a great solution, but dont do it before the exam.

questions.question_text: A recent vulnerability was discovered in the code a company is running on its network devices. The vendor has released a security patch to address the vulnerability. To ensure an unaltered version of the patch is downloaded, which of the following should the network technician validate before installing the patch?
Which of the following DNS record types assists with the routing of email?

choices.B: Limit the network downtime to a maximum of 48 hours per year.
choices.D: Require 48 hours of system backup maintenance.
choices.A: Recover all systems to a loss of 48 hours of data.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Option C: Recover all systems within 48 hours.

RTO stands for Recovery Time Objective, which is the maximum allowable downtime or duration of a service outage after a disaster or disruption. It means how long it will take to recover the system or service to normal operations after a disaster or incident.

In this case, the management team has set a 48-hour RTO, which means that all critical systems should be fully operational within 48 hours after a disaster occurs. Option C is the only answer that aligns with the policy's requirements, as it explicitly states the goal of recovering all systems within the required time frame.
RTO means Recovery Time Object and than answer make sense..

questions.question_text: The management team has instituted a 48-hour RTO as part of the disaster recovery plan. Which of the following procedures would meet the policy's requirements?

choices.D: The ACL does not accurately reflect current addresses for the web development team.
choices.B: The server IP addresses in the DMZ have changed after migrating to DHCP.
choices.C: The OSPF configuration was not updated to route the new dynamic address spaces.
choices.A: The DNS entries are incorrect for the web development team.

discussion.content: I guess that the key words here are " deny entries " which point us to ACL answer (answer D)

questions.question_text: An organization has migrated the internal network from a static IP addressing scheme to use DHCP. After fully deploying the DHCP solution, users within the web deployment team are unable to access the web server that is hosted in the DMZ. After reviewing the logs, the network technician sees multiple deny entries from the internal network to the DMZ. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?
